claim.text: Alyssa Healy and Alana King went unsold in the WPL Auction, while Lucy Hamilton and Milly Illingworth secured contracts; Meg Lanning became the highest-earning Australian, joining UP Warriorz for AU$325,700.

post_content.heading: WPL Auction Claims Debunked: Players, Teams, and Prices Misrepresented
post_content.body: This claim contains multiple significant factual errors regarding the Women's Premier League (WPL) auctions. Firstly, established players Alyssa Healy and Alana King were *not* unsold; Healy captains UP Warriorz, and King played for RCB. Secondly, Meg Lanning, a prominent Australian captain, was bought by *Delhi Capitals* in the WPL 2023 auction for INR 1.1 Crore, not UP Warriorz for AU$325,700, and she was already the highest-earning Australian then. The claim falsely attributes actual events and player statuses while mixing in potentially obscure names (Lucy Hamilton, Milly Illingworth) to create a misleading narrative, all under the guise of an unspecified, likely non-existent, WPL auction event.
post_content.summary: The claim falsely states that Alyssa Healy and Alana King went unsold, misrepresents Meg Lanning's team and price, and contains multiple inaccuracies regarding WPL player selections.

misinformation_sources.title: Alyssa Healy and Alana King went unsold in the WPL Auction, while Lucy Hamilton and Milly Illingworth secured contracts; Meg Lanning became the highest-earning Australian, joining UP Warriorz for AU$325,700.

details.claim_context: During the Women's Premier League (WPL) Auction, Australian players Alyssa Healy and Alana King did not receive contracts, whereas Lucy Hamilton and Milly Illingworth were successfully signed. Former national captain Meg Lanning was the highest-earning Australian, securing a contract with the UP Warriorz for AU$325,700.
